item.description: AP - U.S. intelligence agencies are turning their efforts toward rounding up remaining principals of Saddam Hussein's regime who may be playing a more direct role than the now-captured former president did in running guerrilla operations in Iraq, officials say.
item.title: U.S. Focuses on Remaining Iraqi Figures (AP)

item.description: AP - U.S. troops killed 11 attackers after being ambushed in a town north of Baghdad, the military said Tuesday, while a roadside bomb wounded three soldiers in Saddam Hussein's hometown of Tikrit.
item.title: U.S. Troops Kill 11 in Iraq After Ambush (AP)

item.description: AP - Consumer prices dipped by 0.2 percent in November, pulled down by cheaper gasoline, clothes and airline fares, fresh evidence that inflation isn't a problem even as the economy has shifted into a higher gear.
item.title: Consumer Prices Dip 0.2 Percent in Nov. (AP)

item.description: AP - President Bush is clearing his desk before the holidays, signing seven bills that will stem the flood of unwanted e-mail pitches, help needy families buy their first homes and give flight attendants lessons in self-defense.
item.title: Bush to Sign 'Can Spam' Measure, 6 Others (AP)

item.description: AP - Ozzy Osbourne is joking with nurses — asking two to marry him — but will probably take six months to fully recover from his quad bike crash injuries, his wife Sharon said Tuesday.
item.title: Sharon: Ozzy to Take 6 Months to Recover (AP)

item.description: AP - You've heard of road rage, but local authorities are investigating what appears to be a new modern malady: checkout rage.
item.title: Pa. Authorities Probe Checkout Rage Case (AP)

item.description: AP - Stocks are set to open higher Tuesday, although analysts don't see many market drivers. The Dow rose 19 points recently to 10,044. Nasdaq futures rose half a point, and Standard & Poor's futures inched up 1.1 points.
item.title: Dow, Nasdaq Set to Open Higher (AP)

item.description: AP - Donovan McNabb passed for 236 yards, receiver Freddie Mitchell threw for a touchdown and Philadelphia extended its winning streak to nine games Monday night by beating the Dolphins 34-27, pushing them to the brink of elimination from the playoff race.
item.title: Eagles Defeat the Dolphins 34-27 (AP)

item.description: AP - Medical and women's groups are asking the government to allow a morning-after pill to sell without a prescription, saying easier access could prevent more than a million unplanned pregnancies and hundreds of thousands of abortions every year.
item.title: FDA to Debate Morning-After Prescription (AP)

item.description: Reuters - The U.S. Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff Gen. Richard Myers said during a previously unannounced visit to Baghdad Tuesday that the capture of Saddam Hussein would hurt the anti-American insurgency.
item.title: Gen. Myers Says Saddam Arrest Will Hurt Insurgents (Reuters)

item.description: AP - U.S. special envoy James A. Baker III kicked off a European mission Tuesday to win support for Iraq's reconstruction from some of the staunchest opponents to the Iraq war — starting with France.
item.title: Baker Has 'Fruitful' Talks With Chirac (AP)

item.description: Reuters - A top Vatican official said Tuesday he felt pity and compassion for Saddam Hussein and criticized the U.S. military for showing video footage of him being treated "like a cow."
item.title: Cardinal Says U.S. Treated Saddam 'Like a Cow' (Reuters)

item.description: Reuters - Fresh violence Tuesday showed Saddam Hussein's capture offered no quick solution to Iraq's woes, but U.S. leaders hoped it would help win global allies for their plan to speed up Iraqi self-government.
item.title: Iraqi Violence Flares, Even After Saddam (Reuters)

item.description: Reuters - Egyptian mediators returned to Gaza for a new round of talks with Palestinian factions Tuesday, but Israel ruled out a demand from militant groups that it must also guarantee any cease-fire.
item.title: Israel Rejects Truce as Mediators Return to Gaza (Reuters)

item.description: Reuters - U.S. special envoy James Baker and French President Jacques Chirac agreed at talks Tuesday that their countries must cooperate over efforts to rebuild Iraq, Chirac's office said.
item.title: France, U.S. Agree Must Cooperate to Rebuild Iraq (Reuters)

item.description: The New York Times - Howard Dean declared that Saddam Hussein's capture "has not made America safer," provoking new attacks from rivals.
item.title: Dean's Speech on Iraq Brings Rebuttals From Rivals (The New York Times)

item.description: The New York Times - When G.I.'s uncovered Saddam Hussein in a hide-out, one of them had a greeting, "President Bush sends his regards."
item.title: After 12 Years, Sweet Victory: The Bushes' Pursuit of Hussein (The New York Times)

item.description: The New York Times - The incident appeared to be a further sign that the insurgency has not slowed after the capture of Saddam Hussein.
item.title: U.S. Troops Kill 11 Insurgents After Ambush (The New York Times)

item.description: The New York Times - Car bombs that killed six people were an apparent sign that the insurgency is continuing despite the capture of Saddam Hussein.
item.title: 2 Car Bombers Attack Iraqi Police, as Insurgency Continues (The New York Times)

item.description: USATODAY.com - The capture of Saddam Hussein raises a range of questions about his legal status and future, as well as the United States' responsibilities under international law in dealing with him. Among them:
item.title: As POW, Saddam will be held according to international law (USATODAY.com)

item.description: USATODAY.com - President Bush refused Monday to be drawn into debate on how the capture of Saddam Hussein and U.S. policies in Iraq might affect his re-election, even though much of the discourse among Democratic candidates was focused on that topic.
item.title: 'Forget politics,' president says in discussing event (USATODAY.com)

item.description: USATODAY.com - The U.S. government, rushing to deal with a daunting flu season, said Monday that it has bought 375,000 more doses of flu shots for adults and negotiated an option to buy 3 million doses of nasal spray flu vaccine.
item.title: U.S. buys 375,000 flu shots, eyes 3M mist vaccines (USATODAY.com)

item.description: USATODAY.com - The presidential campaign has entered the post-Saddam era. In a political environment transformed for now by the capture of Saddam Hussein, the spotlight Monday was on Howard Dean, the Democratic candidate most identified with opposition to the Iraq war.
item.title: Saddam's capture forces Dean to reshape message (USATODAY.com)

item.description: USATODAY.com - The U.S. government, rushing to deal with a daunting flu season, said Monday that it has bought 375,000 more doses of flu shots for adults and negotiated an option to buy 3 million doses of nasal spray flu vaccine.
item.title: Government buys 375,000 more flu shots (USATODAY.com)

item.description: The New York Times - Capturing Saddam Hussein is a necessary step to defeat the insurgents, but it is not sufficient to achieve a lasting victory.
item.title: For U.S. Foes, a Major Blow: Fighters Now Lack a Symbol (The New York Times)

item.description: washingtonpost.com - President Bush, savoring Saddam Hussein's capture by U.S. troops, said yesterday in a White House news conference that the United States would arrange for the former Iraqi leader to be judged by his fellow countrymen in a public trial that details his many atrocities.
item.title: Hussein's Fate in Iraqis' Hands (washingtonpost.com)

item.description: washingtonpost.com - DAWR, Iraq, Dec. 15 -- In the small hut near the hole where former president Saddam Hussein spent his final hours of freedom, a dozen books were piled on top of a chest near the bed. There was a book on interpreting dreams, volumes of classical Arabic poetry titled "Discipline" and "Sin," and Fyodor Dostoyevsky's "Crime and Punishment."
item.title: Small, Cluttered Refuge Was a Far Cry From Luxury (washingtonpost.com)

item.description: washingtonpost.com - BAGHDAD, Dec. 14 -- Thirty-eight weeks after the United States began stalking Saddam Hussein with an arsenal of lethal force, technology and coercion, it fell to a soldier with a spade to flush the fallen leader from a hole.
item.title: When Focus Shifted Beyond Inner Circle, U.S. Got a Vital Clue (washingtonpost.com)
